entry.title: Re: Personalized Recommendations in SAP SuccessFactors Opportunity Marketplace: Logic and Data Sourc
entry.content:
@ChrisPaine  Thank you! 

Most of these recommendations require a minimum amount of data. I should have included that in this blog :). There is definitely a threshold, and it differs for each recommendation type (not customer), for the ML model to work! I will get that info and add it to the blog in the coming weeks. 

Yes, the models are being worked/adjusted/improved periodically. The quality of the recommendation also improves if more people are in the system and utilizing the data.

entry.title: Connecting Datasphere to Salesforce using Generic HTTP connection and API Task
entry.content:
Hi All,

We are trying to connect to Salesforce using the Generic HTTP connection along with the API Task feature. We have confirmed by sending request through Postman that access token is getting generated successfully using the same connection details as configured in the Generic HTTP connection shown in the below screenshot:

But while using the same connection in API Task to connect to Salesforce we are getting "Failed to fetch the access token" error while doing a API Test Run. We are using the following Generic API settings within the API Task:

Would like to know if anything needs to be done differently to make the API Task function as expected.

Regards,

DS

2. access policy-IntegrationFlowAccess - gave it 3 artifact references to packageA, packageB, packageC.

Created a userA - with Roles - CatalogPackagesCopy, AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper, APIProxy.Developer - did NOT grant him the custom Role that matches the 2 access policies above.

UserA is able to view and edit the packages ...!

What am i missing here.

entry.title: Designing Value Help Services for the Situation Handling - Extended Framework
entry.content:
Understanding Value Help Services: What They Are and Why They Matter?

Value help services are a cornerstone feature in enhancing user experience by offering context-specific assistance. These services provide users with relevant suggestions and options based on the current situation, making tasks more intuitive and efficient. But what exactly are value help services, and how do they help users? Let's dive into their key functions and benefits.

Key Functions and Benefits of Value Help Services

  • Easing Data Entry
    One of the primary goals of value help services is to simplify data entry. For instance, when inputting data like product lists or options that require predefined choices, these services provide a seamless way to select the appropriate data. This reduces the risk of errors and speeds up the data input process.
  • Use in Situation Handling
    Value help services are particularly useful when it comes to defining condition filters for situation templates and types in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app, as well as in the My Situations ‚Äì Extended app as part of the filter bar. By offering context-specific suggestions, they help users navigate and interact with the system more efficiently, turning complex tasks into manageable ones.

Let's take a closer look at how these services work with an example. Figure 1 below shows how you can choose a plane type when defining a condition filter in the Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended app. Value help services ensure that when you don't have to manually input each plane type; instead, you can select from a list of predefined options. You also see additional information, such as the total seats of the plane, that help you choose the appropriate plane type.

Throughout this blog, we'll continue to use the plane type value help as an example to illustrate how value help services enhance user experience and streamline processes.


Figure 1: Value Help for Plane Type in Condition Filter dialog in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app 

Designing an OData-Based Value Help Service

In this section, we explore the design of an OData-based value help service, breaking down its key components and steps. This will serve as a foundation for integrating these services into the extended framework for Situation Handling. We‚Äôll use artifacts from the Flight situation object (ID: SITDEMO_FLIGHT), which is included as a demo object in the extended framework. The main components and their relations are shown in Figure 2 below:


Figure 2: Overview on Artifacts for the Value Help Definition

Key Components of an OData-Based Value Help

  • CDS Views
    • Value Help Source CDS View: Define the source entity that serves as the primary data source for the value help service. This view and its view entities are referenced from the situation object.
    • Value Help Provider CDS View(s): Design one or more CDS views specifically for the value help, which may include additional filters or joins to meet the value help requirements.
      Both the base CDS view as well as the Value Help Provider Views contain annotations that are essential for enhancing the functionality and user experience of value helps.
  • OData Service
    Naturally, OData-based value helps must be exposed as OData services to be accessible to SAP Fiori applications including their respective Service Definition and Business Service.
  • Situation Object
    Linking the source CDS view in a situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app.

Steps to Design an OData-Based Value Help Service

1. Define the Value Help Source CDS View

Start by creating the source CDS view, which will serve as the primary data source for your value help. This view should include all relevant fields that users might need for filtering or searching. Below is an example based on the Sitn2DemoFlightVH view provided by SAP:

@ObjectModel.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@ObjectModel.dataCategory: #VALUE_HELP
define view entity C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH as select from R_Sitn2DemoFlight {
  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition:[{entity: {name: 'C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH', element: 'SitnDemoPlaneType'}}]  
      key cast( '' as sit2_demo_plane_type ) as SitnDemoPlaneType
}

This view only serves to reference the value helps for the entity sets it contains ‚Äì it is not necessary to actually retrieve all field values here, i.e., as shown in the above entity set, it is possible to simply hard-code the field value as ''. The important annotations in this view are the @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition annotations which define the Value Help Provider View (entity.name) and the element (entity.element) in the target entity that is linked to the respective fields (SitnDemoPlaneVH and SitnDemoPlaneType in the example above). For more details, check out the Consumption Annotations page in SAP Help Portal.

2. Create the Value Help Provider View

Next, create a CDS view specifically for the value help.[1] This view may include filters, joins, or additional fields necessary for the value help functionality.

@ObjectModel.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@ObjectModel.dataCategory: #VALUE_HELP
@ObjectModel.representativeKey: 'SitnDemoPlaneType'
define view entity C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH as select from R_Sitn2DemoPlane
{
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true
@Search.ranking: #HIGH
key SitnDemoPlaneType,

@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.ranking: #LOW
SitnDemoSeatsMaxQty,
... 
}

Besides the SitnDemoPlaneType, that was referenced by the entity.element in the Source CDS View above and must be part of the Value Help Provider View, the view incorporates extra fields like the number of seats available. To enhance user experience, the view can also include optional search annotations.

3. Expose as OData Service

Finally, expose the value help CDS view as an OData service to make it accessible to SAP Fiori applications and other systems consuming OData services. Currently, only OData V2 services are supported that needs to be implemented by using Business Service. Ensure the Service Definition includes the Source CDS View and all referenced Value Help Provider Views, like in the example below:

@EndUserText.label: 'Value help for Situation Demo'
define service C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVHSRV {
expose C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH as FlightVH;
expose C_Sitn2DemoPlaneVH as PlaneVH;
}

This service definition is afterwards used for the service binding. Please use ‚ÄúOData V2 ‚Äì UI‚Äù as binding type. The result should look like the service binding below:[2]


Figure 3: Service Binding for Value Help Service

Extending a Situation Object with a Value Help

We'll now guide you through the steps to add a value help service in the Manage Situation Objects app. To do so, open your situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app. We are again using the Flight situation object (ID: SITDEMO_FLIGHT) that comes with the extended framework, but with a different service that got exposed using Business Services.

Add a Value Help Service in the Manage Situation Objects App

  1. Create a New Value Help Service
    To add a new value help service, you'll start by clicking the "Create" button in your situation object in the Manage Situation Objects app.
  2. Configure the Value Help Service
    in the Value Help Services section, fill the following fields with the specified values:
    1. Service Protocol Version: Set this to V2.
    2. Service Path: Choose Standard - there are currently no other options available.
    3. Service Binding: Enter the name of the service binding of the value help service you‚Äôve created. In the example shown in Figure 3, this is C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVHV2.
    4. Service Version: Use the latest service version from your service binding.In the example shown in Figure 3, this version is 1.
  3. Add Properties.
    Add the entity set of the Source CDS View here, not any of the Value Help Provider Views that are also included in the service. Please note that you have to use the name of the entity set as defined in the Service Definition, not the name of the CDS view, i.e. for our example use FlightVH and not C_Sitn2DemoFlightVH. Add the name of the property that you want to use.

The results should look like the figure below:


Figure 4: Manage Situation Objects: add a Value Help Service

Mapping Value Help Entities in the Situation Object Structures

To complete your value help setup, you provide a mapping between the fields of the CDS views you use in the structure of your situation object and the properties in the value help service entities. We'll walk you through the necessary steps to do this below:

  1. Open the Structure in the Manage Situation Objects app
    Navigate to the structure within your situation object that you wish to extend with value help functionality.
  2. Access the Value Help Mapping Section
    Next, go to the "Value Help Mapping" section. This is where you will map the fields to the value help entities.
  3. Create a New Mapping
    1. Click on the "Create" button to add a new value help mapping.
    2. Select a Field: Choose the field from the structure that you want to enhance with a value help. For our example, we're using SITNDEMOPLANETYPE.
    3. Assign the Value Help
      After selecting the field, use the value help to select the value help ID you modeled in the previous steps. Ensure you match the entity set and property correctly. For our example, the mapping should be:
      Value Help ID: VALUE_HELP_DEMO
      Entity Set: FlightVH
      Property: SitnDemoPlaneType

The results should look like the figure below:


Figure 5: Manage Situation Objects: mapping of Value Help Service and Structure fields

By following these steps, you'll successfully add the value help service to your situation object, enhancing your ability to manage situations effectively.

Using the Situation Object Enhanced with Value Help Services

Once you've created your situation objects and enhanced them with value help services, they're ready for use in situation scenarios, situation templates, and situation types. Most of your defined content is automatically propagated, making changes‚Äîeven in value help services‚Äîimmediately active.

However, situation type updates are handled different due to performance caching. If you add value help services after creating a situation type, you'll need to refresh it by creating a new version of the situation type. You can do this by making a small change for example in the type description and saving afterwards. This will trigger the value help changes to become active. For any situation type you create after enhancing your situation objects, the changes will immediately be applied.

Tips and tricks for testing and in case of problems

Testing your value help service

To quickly test if your value help service works correctly, create a new situation template that makes use of the situation object[3] that you‚Äôve defined and check the condition filters. Make sure to select the correct trigger or anchor object for the condition filter to see all fields and their value helps.
An example for the Demo Scenario is shown in Figure 1 Value Help for Plane Type in Condition Filter dialog in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app.

Check the $metadata of your value help service

When the value helps are not working, please check the $metadata of your service. All fields with value help services should have the <Annotation Term="Common.ValueList"> property.

An example is the $metadata of the Demo Application

URL: ‚Ä¶/sap/opu/odata/sap/C_SITN2DEMOFLIGHTVH_CDS/$metadata 

<Annotation Term="Common.ValueList">
...
<Record>
<PropertyValue Property="CollectionPath" String="C_Sitn2DemoRegionVH" />
...
</Annotations>

Similar annotation should be available in the OData Service defined in the Service Binding. Simply extend the service URL with /$metadata and check the properties you annotated. There should be a Common.ValueList annotation for each field annotated with @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition in your Source CDS View.

Creating or Updating Situation Types after Situation Object Changes

As mentioned earlier (section ‚ÄúUsing the Value Help enhanced objects‚Äù) remember that situation objects are cached for performance reasons in situation types when the situation type is created. This means that changes in the situation object are not reflected for the existing situation types, even if you might see them already in the situation template, unless they are updated.
So, whenever an update of situation objects was required, please remember to change or create new situation types to reflect the changes.

Update structure mapping after changing Value Help Services

Whenever you update a value help service in a situation object, , make sure to also update the value help mapping in the respective structure of the situation object.
Figure 6 shows an example where the entity set is wrong (ZAS_VH_BASE_VIRE) and should be changed to the correct name of the entity set as it‚Äôs exposed in the service (-> FlightVH). Once this was changed in the Value Help section, it also needs to be changed in the Value Help Mapping in the Structure section(s).


Figure 6: Manage Situation Object: Reflect changes in Value Help also to the Structure Mapping.

Popup ‚ÄúNo authorization to access value help for <<FIELDNAME>> . Please define conditions‚Äù

While using the condition filter dialog, you might encounter the following error:
Figure 7: Popup ‚ÄúNo authorization to access value help for <<FIELDNAME>> . Please define conditions‚Äù

This error can arise from two primary issues:

  1. Value Help Service Authorization: There may be an authorization problem with the value help service, which needs to be addressed in the backend ‚Äì check the DCLs assigned to the views and the authorizations given to the user.
  2. Service Issues: The service itself might be experiencing problems.

Troubleshooting Steps:
To diagnose if the issue is with the service, use the browser‚Äôs network tab in the debugging tools to check for a /$metadata request related to your value help service.
Here‚Äôs what you might find:

  • Service Not Published: If the service URL is unavailable, it‚Äôs likely that the service hasn‚Äôt been published. Ensure that the service is properly published.
  • Wrong OData Version: If you see an error message similar to
<code>/IWFND/MED/170</code>
<message xml:lang="en">No service found for namespace '', name '...', version '0001'</message>
<innererror>‚Äã

it‚Äôs probable that the incorrect OData version was used. Ensure you are using ‚ÄúOData V2 ‚Äì UI‚Äù as specified in the ‚ÄúExpose as OData Service‚Äù step in the section ‚ÄúSteps to Design an OData-Based Value Help Service.‚Äù

By following these steps, you should be able to identify and resolve the underlying issue causing the error.

Conclusion

Modeling value help services for the extended framework for Situation Handling is a powerful way to enhance user experience by providing context-specific assistance. By following the principles and best practices demonstrated in the Flight Demo, experienced developers can create robust and effective value help services tailored to their projects.
Stay tuned for more advanced techniques and in-depth discussions as we continue to explore the capabilities of the extended framework for Situation Handling.
Happy coding!

Footnotes:

[1] Multiple Value Help Provider Views need to be created when the source CDS view references several Value Help Provider Views in the annotations.
[2]  Note -This service does not exist in the Flight situation object that uses a different mechanism. However, the target design is to use service bindings.
[3]  When creating the situation template, you first need to create a situation scenario where the situation object that is enhanced with value help services is used as trigger or anchor object. The value help becomes visible in the value help for the field it got assigned to in the condition‚Äôs filters of the trigger or anchor object.

entry.title: JDBC (Microsoft SQL) Connectivity issue In SAP CPI
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm trying to establish a connection to an on prem Microsoft SQL server via JDBC adapter in SAP CPI. I'm getting an error
org.springframework.jdbc.CannotGetJdbcConnectionException: Failed to obtain JDBC Connection; nested exception is com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: The TCP/IP connection to the host localhost, port 1106 has failed. Error: "The driver received an unexpected pre-login response. Verify the connection properties and check that an instance of SQL Server is running on the host and accepting TCP/IP connections at the port. This driver can be used only with SQL Server 2005 or later.". ClientConnectionId:1fe33d15-3b89-41fa-b211-672cb643ff12, cause: com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: The TCP/IP connection to the host localhost, port 1106 has failed. Error: "The driver received an unexpected pre-login response. Verify the connection properties and check that an instance of SQL Server is running on the host and accepting TCP/IP connections at the port. This driver can be used only with SQL Server 2005 or later.". ClientConnectionId:1fe33d15-3b89-41fa-b211-672cb643ff12
The driver I've installed in CPI is V8.4.1

My JDBC configuration is 

Is this the correct driver version I'm using, and in the error, it mentions port as 1106, I've not maintained that port, why is it coming in the error? How do I resolve this error?

Please help.

Thanks in advance!
Shreyas.

entry.title: Use of VBA macro "Workbook_BeforeSave" in SAP DM
entry.content:
Hi,

We have embedded a VBA macro in a module within an Excel file. This macro needs to run before the file is saved. Consequently, we inserted the following code into "ThisWorkbook":

Private Sub Workbook_BeforeSave(ByVal SaveAsUI As Boolean, Cancel As Boolean)

Call Primadichiudere 'Name of the macro

End Sub

When we use the file outside of SAP DM, everything works correctly. However, when we test the Excel file after uploading it to SAP DM, we have noticed the following:

  • If we run the macro manually (F5), it works and executes correctly.
  • If we save the file using the floppy disk icon (i.e., not in SAP DM), it works correctly.
  • If we try to save with "apply changes," the macro doesn't work. It doesn't give any error messages, so it's not a debug issue; it simply fails to do what it's supposed to do (e.g. it doesn't copy or paste values)

Is this normal, or are we doing something wrong? Is there a way to solve this issue?

Thank you very much,

Sofia

entry.title: From Movie Theater to Global Stage: How a "Gully Boy" Moment Changed Everything
entry.content:
In a darkened movie theater in Amsterdam, Nagesh Polu made a decision that would seem absurd to most people. Fifteen minutes into the film, he'd already guessed the ending (he is an avid movie goer, so this happens often). So, he did what any dedicated learner would do‚Äîhe pulled out his phone and started studying SAP SuccessFactors materials instead.

"That's probably the weirdest place I've ever studied," Nagesh laughs, "but it perfectly captures who I am. I can't waste a moment when there's something new to learn."

Nagesh's story begins in Chirala, India, where he earned his bachelor's degree. His parents had instilled in him what he calls a "do-or-die mindset"‚Äîa philosophy that would prove prophetic.

 

"My father taught me that success isn't just about personal achievement," Nagesh reflects. "It's about lifting your family and extended family along with you. Living simply, staying cheerful, standing by our people‚Äîthese weren't just values, they were survival strategies.‚Äù Those early years built something invaluable: resilience. Little did he know that this small-town foundation would eventually support a career spanning continents and transforming global enterprises.

Starting as a sales trainee, Nagesh eventually found himself at YASH Technologies, working with traditional SAP HCM presales teams and constantly hitting walls. During one particularly frustrating project estimations discussions, a senior consultant delivered advice that would change everything: "If you really want to shape the future, learn SAP‚Äîit's where the biggest challenges and opportunities are."

But it was SAP's acquisition of SuccessFactors that created Nagesh's true "lightbulb moment." While others saw a complex transition, he saw infinite possibility. What happened next was nothing short of extraordinary.

SAP Learning Hub became Nagesh's compass‚Äîhis "go-to resource for quickly building knowledge and completing prerequisites." The comprehensive training, hands-on exercises, and certification preparation materials became the foundation of his transformation. The breakthrough came during a late-night session in his Amsterdam home office. He was trying to build a complex report. Hours of trial and error had left him exhausted and frustrated. Then, using the detailed training materials and practical examples from SAP Learning Hub, it clicked. "I sat there thinking, 'I can build anything with this.' The rush was incredible‚Äù, he remembers.

Here's where Nagesh's story takes a surprising turn. He expected SAP learning to be purely technical‚Äîa skills upgrade to advance his career. Instead, it transformed something he never anticipated: his ability to think like a business leader. The intensive learning journey wouldn't have been possible without key support. Nagesh credits his wife as his anchor, whose unwavering support at home enabled his relentless pursuit of learning without interruption and his mentors across his journey.

Colleagues began noticing that Nagesh brought both big-picture strategy and hands-on expertise to projects. He wasn't just solving technical problems; he was solving business problems.

As Nagesh accumulated SAP Certifications‚Äî through rigorous study with SAP Learning Hub‚Äîeach one became what he calls "another layer of armor."

"Every SAP Certification reinforced my ability not only to tackle complex projects but also to lead others through them," he shares. "They weren't just credentials‚Äîthey were confidence multipliers."

The SAP Certifications opened doors to high-impact global assignments and helped him earn client trust more quickly. But the real transformation was internal: from a small-town graduate to a leader who could walk into any boardroom with complete confidence.

Then came the career-defining moment that validated years of relentless learning. A global client was facing a high-stakes SAP SuccessFactors implementation with a brutal deadline. Their previous attempts had failed. The pressure was immense. Nagesh delivered.

"When their CHRO told me that our solution had transformed how they manage talent worldwide, all those years of learning‚Äîincluding those movie theater study sessions‚Äîsuddenly made perfect sense," he recalls. Today, Nagesh's learning journey continues to impact others in unexpected ways. He's mentored colleagues through their first SAP Certifications, elevated his entire team's capabilities, and regularly shares insights through blogs that help the wider SAP community.

 "My learning journey has been consistent, persistent, and purpose-driven," he notes. "It should be as natural as checking your messages or having your morning coffee."

When asked what movie would capture his learning journey, Nagesh's answer is immediate: "Gully Boy‚ÄîApna time aayega" (Our time will come). It perfectly captures his philosophy: that with persistent learning and unwavering commitment, anyone from anywhere can rise to extraordinary heights. From a movie theater in Amsterdam to global boardrooms, from a small coastal town to becoming a trusted advisor to multinational corporations, Nagesh's story proves a simple truth: learning isn't just about acquiring skills‚Äîit's about transforming your entire life.

Ready to start your own transformation? Benefit from tailored and self-paced learning opportunities that meet you when and where you learn best on the SAP Learning site. Get certified to demonstrate your expertise and boost your career.

entry.title: Re: Universal OData ‚Üî MCP Bridge; Or: How I Accidentally Made 15,000 Enterprise Services Talk to AI
entry.content:
@dariusz_michalczuk2 it is also supporting --cookie auth, so it would be good-enough to to test/play with dev system: you can login into the system via web (into Fiori) export cookie and then use this exported cookie for temporarily login.

For permanent solution some full SAML choreography would be required which is quite challenging. But simpler approach might be possible: enabling OAuth for particular OData service (?).

entry.title: After sending a customer invoice e-invoice to a yahoo mail account I can not download attachments
entry.content:
After sending an e-invoice to the mentioned web browser email application you can only see the attachment content as raw data.

As this is the browser application  concept from yahoo, aol and similar (XML are not meant for humans), we recommend as a workaround to use 

outlook, thunderstorm or similar.

 

Here you are able to download all xml attachments

entry.title: Business Partner Relationship WebService Inbound
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

i am working on an interface between Salesforce and SAP and i am using the Inbound Business Partner/Business Partner Relationship Service.

Because of the format of the SalesForce ID( e.g. 003bY00000lm0NyQAI ) it is not possible to fill the field "InternalID" in the Request for Business Partner Creation. So im am using the field "ExternalID" which works in general and the key mapping is created.

But when i try to use the external keys for the relationship:

the following error occours:

I tried it with the fields ReceiverBusinessPartnerInternalID/ReceiverRelationshipBusinessPartnerInternalID and it works. But if the contact is not created yet, i do not have the ReceiverRelationshipBusinessPartnerInternalID at that time.

To my understanding this should work with the external keys aswell, where SAP is searching for the Internal Business Partner Numbers in the Key Mapping Table.

I would appreciate any hints on this topic üôÇ

Regards

Simon

entry.title: SAP UI5: PDFViewer with flag isTrustedSource=true gives error
entry.content:
Hello, 

we have an application which uses PDFViewer with the property isTrustedSource="true". However the PDF does not load, instead I can see an error in the console saying "Error: Underlying iframe was not found in DOM.".  The application is running inside a Launchpad.

I already searched the forums, everyone is suggesting setting isTrustedSource to true, which we did. However the error is showing. Is there another cause which I can take a look at?

Thanks a lot in advance!

entry.title: Re: SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public J78 Cash Flow reconciliation
entry.content:
Hi,

 This is not an answer but more insight provided in the absence of Reka.

Please, find more details below in the application of the  J78 test script

The user ID is : CB9980000022

Perform a Cash flow reconciliation :

The Client needs to use the manual Cash Flow reconciliation, so we applied the J78 test script to do so and used the app ‚ÄúReconcile cash flow‚Äù.

The process specifies that we need a bank statement flow and a memo record.

First, in the Reprocess bank statement app you can see there are many bank statements, but these items don‚Äôt appear in the reconcile cash flow app :

 

So we created a memo record to make sure there is at least one :

we used the "Manage Memo Records " app. 

The credit memo displayed properly on the right table : 

The memo record appears in the intraday cash flow reconciliation, however, I didn‚Äôt have the left part and could not perform any reconciliation.

So we called the app : Reconcile cash flow

Chose "Adapt Filters if selection fields are hidden".

Made the following entries and chose Go:

Value Date: <current date>

Exchange Rate Type: M

Reconciliation Profile: EOD_PROF/INTRA_PROF

Company Code: DE0

Bank Account: For example, 221597028

No pending reconciliation appeared :

when clearing the filter "reconciliation status", two records appear but still not the one expected.

Does anyone have an idea about what we dis wrong?

Best regards

entry.title: SAP Build Issues with S/4 HANA Attachments for Controlling Documents
entry.content:
Hello,

We've found a potential bug with the SAP Build attachments process with S/4 HANA (version 2020).  When we use the POST AttachmentContentSet method for accounting documents (BusinessObjectType = BKPF) we are able to see the attachments after the process runs.  We check them in SAP GUI or Fiori.  

However, when we attempt to use the same method with FIN Controlling documents (BusinessObjectType = BUS2072), we are only able to see the attachments in SAP GUI or Fiori if someone creates an attachment through the GUI or Fiori first.  If no attachment is created through the GUI or Fiori, the attachments created by SAP Build through the POST AttachmentContentSet method are not visible in the GUI or Fiori.

MS Copilot reports that this is because there is no BINARY_RELATION_CREATE_COMMIT with BusinessObjectType = BUS2072, but there is with BusinessObjectType = BKPF.  While I cannot confirm this, I was hoping an expert in the community might be able to confirm if this is a bug?

entry.title: Install SAP build process automation desktop agent for macOS
entry.content:
Hello community,

I want to install desktop agent for macOS but I can't find a way to get the installer. I've followed instructions in SAP help (https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/install-macos-agent-3?locale=en-US) but the installer doesn't appear on the download page of build process automation -> control tower -> agents.

I am working on a BTP trial account, macOS version Sequoia 15.6.1, chip Apple M3 max.

I appreciate any help you can give me.

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: How to create a user group with limited permissions in SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
Hello,

I need to create a user group with limited permissions in SAP Customer Data Cloud.

The requirements are:

  • The user group should be able to view registered users and edit their profile data.
  • The user group should also be able to edit the email templates.

For the user management part, I was able to configure the permissions successfully. However, for the email template editing, I am not sure which permissions need to be assigned.

I even tried granting all available permissions, but I still receive an error when attempting to edit the templates.

Could anyone provide guidance on which exact role or permission setup is required for this use case?

Thanks in advance,

Stefania

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì [Updated] Moving from Standalone to Embedded Deployment in SAP Fiori
entry.content:
Important to know (and unfortunately, this took several days of self-study and support from SAP): Transporting the catalogs from the standalone Fiori server to the embedded backend system is language-dependent! In other words, despite successfully exporting the catalogs to the backend system, none of the exported catalogs and groups were displayed in the target system.

"While there are xxx FLP relevant CUST Webdynpro component configurations in table WDY_CONF_USER, only for y of them, there are entries in table WDY_CONF_USERT. FLP cannot work with WDY_CONF_USER entries not having at least one corresponding WDY_CONF_USERT entry.  The transports WDY_CONF_USER keys are all English but entries in WDY_CONF_USERT are in German. You may create the transports again when having logged in in German."

entry.title: Re: Seeing "Bad Installation" error while loading the ret...
entry.content:
‚Ä¢ Ensure the sl_sdk.jar file is added to your project Libraries.

‚Ä¢ Verify that the  -Dbusinessobjects.connectivity.directory is correctly set as follows:
    -Dbusinessobjects.connectivity.directory="<bip-install-dir>\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\dataAccess\connectionServer"

‚Ä¢ Confirm that your client is properly configured to access the database defined in the connection.

‚Ä¢ Make sure the Connection Server binaries directory is included in your system PATH environment variable.
   set PATH=<bip-install-dir>\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win64_x86;%path%

...

hope that helps!

entry.title: Solution Order Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to the 2508 update for everyone looking to grow their revenues with solution-based business models  powered by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition! As always, there‚Äôs a lot to get excited about with this release of the cloud ERP and you can find out about a few of the spotlight features from head of Cloud ERP Product Success Bert Schulze. In this blog we‚Äôll zoom in on new features in the Solution Order Management area which you can put straight into use to grow your solution selling prowess. 
 
If you‚Äôre short on time, my AI alter-ego gives a quick summary of the key highlights in the below video‚Ä¶.  

 


 
Let's dive into the details of each feature. 
 
Introducing Service Bundles in Solution Orders 
 
Solution bundles have been supported since 2024, enabling the sale of pre-defined stand-alone packages which consist of a mixture of multiple item types, such as physical goods, services and subscription products. With 2502, we expanded on this capability more with the introduction of bundle pricing for greater flexibility, and now in 2508, we again grow the bundle selling capability of Solution Order Management by supporting Service Bundles. From this release, users can benefit from the inclusion of service bundles, either with a fixed-price or time-and-material service bundles, in their solution orders.  

By selling pre-defined packages that can be automatically exploded into their individual components, you not only reduce manual maintenance effort but also minimize the risk of input errors. These service bundles offer robust capabilities similar to a standard service order, including contract determination, price calculation, and more. Once you release a service bundle‚Äîor a broader solution bundle containing one‚Äîthe system automatically generates the corresponding follow-up service order, streamlining the entire fulfilment process from delivery of products to executing the service. 

 

 
Flexible Quantity for Subscription Billing Items 
 
A key facet of solution orders is the ability to sell subscriptions alongside further item types in a single solution order. However, a significant limitation in previous releases was the inability to specify a quantity greater than one for subscription-based items in a solution order. If a customer wished to purchase 20 licenses for 20 different pieces of equipment in a solution order, the highly inefficient process of creating 20 separate subscription line items was required to record and bill corresponding usage data. This not only created excessive manual data entry but also resulted in bloated order documents and complex reporting. 
 
With the 2508 release, we address this operational bottleneck. Within the `Manage Solution Orders` app, the quantity field for any line item categorized for subscription billing is no longer restricted. Users can now simply enter the desired quantity‚Äîfor instance, 20‚Äîin a single line item. In the item view, you‚Äôll see both the‚ÄØaggregated net price‚ÄØfor all subscriptions in that item and a detailed breakdown for each individual subscription. Managing them is easier than ever, too: every generated subscription is clearly listed in the‚ÄØtransaction history‚ÄØand fully visible in the‚ÄØprogress monitor, so you can track execution from order entry through fulfillment with complete transparency. This simple yet critical change radically streamlines the sales process for multi-unit subscriptions and reduces the potential for data entry errors.  

 

Solution Bundle Pricing for Subscription Products  

Whilst we‚Äôre on the subject of subscriptions, another key feature being rolled out with the 2508 builds on the bundle pricing functionality linked above. With this release, we now support subscription products with bundle specific pricing meaning subscription products‚ÄØcan now have‚ÄØspecial bundle-specific prices‚ÄØmaintained directly in your Subscription Billing tenant, based on‚ÄØsolution bundle information. Using the‚ÄØManage Lookup Table Data‚ÄØapp in master data, you can define tailored pricing for subscription items sold as part of a bundle and easily compare it to the price of the same product sold standalone. This flexibility lets you create more attractive offers that encourage customers to choose bundled solutions‚Äîdriving higher revenue for your solution business. When you release a solution order containing a bundle, the follow-up subscription is generated automatically, with the bundle ID retained for accurate pricing application and easy tracking throughout the subscription lifecycle. 
 

 

 

Flexible determination of dates in solution order processing 

With 2508, we have enhanced the flexibility of solution selling by enabling the adjustment of certain date parameters in a solution order. In many industries, particularly those with long sales cycles or international operations, a single order date is insufficient. For example, a contract might be signed in one fiscal period, but delivery and invoicing occur in the next, requiring a different posting date for accurate operational reporting. Similarly, pricing might be fixed based on a promotional period that has already passed, or a customer may request a specific future delivery date that dictates logistics planning. Without the ability to set these dates independently, organizations resort to manual overrides or complex workarounds which could introduce a higher risk of errors in revenue recognition, customer billing, and supply chain execution. 
 
With this in mind, we‚Äôve enabled more flexible date entry within the `Manage Solution Orders` application. Users can now explicitly set and manage several key dates at the solution order header level and under the new enhanced date profile on the sales item level. 
 

  • Posting Date: Used for reporting and search purposes in the solution order. 
  • Pricing Date: Determines the exact date for which price conditions, exchange rates, and taxes are applied, allowing for precise control over contract profitability 
  • Billing Date: Sets the baseline date for generating billing documents, providing flexibility in scheduling customer invoices. 
  • Requested Delivery Date: The date communicated by the customer for when goods or services should be received. This date is now a primary input for the Available-to-Promise (ATP) check and subsequent delivery scheduling. 

 

This granularity ensures that each downstream process‚Äîfrom logistics to finance‚Äîis driven by the correct temporal data, leading to greater accuracy and process automation. 
 

 
Tolerant Handling of Incomplete Sales Orders: Incompleteness Checks for Sales Orders from Solution Orders 

By using‚ÄØsales order type OR, you can create sales orders directly from a solution order even when some mandatory information is missing, thanks to built-in‚ÄØincompleteness checks. This means follow-up documents can still be generated, while the system flags any missing data for review. In the‚ÄØprogress monitor, these sales orders appear in a distinct red status, making it clear that action is needed. Incompleteness procedures help you identify and address gaps before further processing, and any orders with incomplete information are clearly listed in the‚ÄØSAP Fiori‚ÄØapp‚ÄØ‚ÄúList Incomplete Sales Documents‚Äù.  

 

Contract Accounts Supported for Service Contract Items 

With the‚ÄØ2508 release,‚ÄØservice contract items‚ÄØin Solution Order Management now support‚ÄØFI-CA (Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable)‚Äîa specialized subledger for high-volume billing and receivables. Building on functionality first introduced in 2502 for sales and subscription items, contract accounts can be maintained at both header and item levels, transferred to follow-up documents on release, and posted directly to FI-CA for streamlined invoicing, payment handling, and financial tracking. This integration centralizes financial data, improves billing accuracy, and provides a clear, consolidated view of customer transactions. 

Pricing Analysis in Solution Orders 
 

In the 2508 release of‚ÄØSolution Order Management, a new‚ÄØprice analysis‚ÄØcapability makes it easier than ever to verify that pricing has been executed correctly on sales order items, service order items, and service contract items. A newly added‚ÄØAnalyze‚ÄØbutton in the‚ÄØPrice Details‚ÄØview lets you drill down into a comprehensive price breakdown for each solution order item, with full visibility into how each‚ÄØprice condition‚ÄØwas determined. This gives you greater transparency, control, and confidence in your pricing‚Äîright where you need it. 


 
Partner data enabled on item level for sales items 
 
A solution sale can often involve multiple stakeholders. With this in mind, in 2508, we enable the partner determination procedure `SAI00003` for sales item categories within solution orders. This enhancement allows users to navigate to any sales line item in the `Manage Solution Orders` app and specify unique partner functions. You can now have one line item with a specific ship-to party and end-user, and another line item within the same order with completely different partners. This information then flows seamlessly to all follow-up documents generated from the solution order, ensuring that deliveries are routed to the correct addresses and invoices are sent to the appropriate contacts, all while maintaining the integrity of the single, comprehensive solution order.  

Solution Order Management OData API V4 Enhancements 

With the previous release, we introduced the enhanced solution order OData V4 API. This updated API optimizes communication, reduces data transfer payloads, and enhances request handling for faster processing and lower resource use, leading to quicker response times and a better user experience. It supports full CRUD operations for managing solution order items, so with 2508 we have expanded its scope to include the new functions described above, including subscription items with greater quantities, and service bundles. Importantly, we have rounded-off the ability to create a solution order touch-free by now supporting subscription billing items via the API operations, enabling specialists to generate solution orders entirely via API containing all possible item types. Additionally, it is easier to identify the documents created from the solution order for further processing and set this up without manual intervention.  

A further API enhancement we are excited to introduce with this release enables you to simulate a solution order in an external quotation system to get accurate and up-to-date values. This is a big step towards more seamless order entry, enabling customers to generate quotes with minimal revisions, delivering a faster turn-around time for quotation conversion and order fulfilment.  


 

 

More Information

If you are interested in the latest and greatest blog posts on Manufacturing, please have a look at my collection blog  and also take a look at the community page for solution business.

 

 

 

Watch the Replays of Our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series!‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand ‚Äì anywhere, anytime. 

‚ÄØ 

 

 

Find All of Our Assets‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

We at Cloud ERP Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Re: SuccessFactors Employee Central HCM Certification
entry.content:
Hello,

You should be able to find all that information via the SAP Learning link below. That should allow you to search courses and details.

https://learning.sap.com/my-learning/certifications

You should also be able to purchase a license through there as well as you will need that to be able to access the courses and get exam attempts.  I think you can get either (2) or (4) attempts.

I hope this helps. Good luck with the certification!

entry.title: Re: Manual Bank Reconciliation Start to End to Process in...
entry.content:
Dear @TAMS1,

Manual bank statements in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are created directly in the system using the Manage Bank Statements app when electronic statements are unavailable or unsupported. Instead of importing files, users enter the data manually or upload it using a spreadsheet template provided within the app to streamline the process.

If you want to go through the end-to-end process for performing manual bank reconciliation, check the following SAP Help links

Read more about the difference between a manually created and an electronically created bank statement.

Manual vs. Electronic Bank Statements | SAP Help Portal

Read here for step-by-step instructions to create a manual bank statement via a spreadsheet template.

How to Upload Bank Statements with a Spreadsheet File | SAP Help Portal

Here for clearing process in AR accounting

Clearing Process | SAP Help Portal

If you need more information or further details, please let me know.

 

Thank you and BR

Dilan

entry.title: Real Time Payment in SAP Business ByDesign
entry.content:
With real-time transfers, also known as instant payments, transfers can be made within seconds. Following the switch to the SEPA transfer procedure, cashless payments in Europe have been further accelerated.

How can we create automatic payments with real-time-transfers in SAP Business ByDesign?
